item.title: Iowa Pandering Has Been Scarce in This Unusual Republican Primary
item.content:encoded: <div> Presidential candidates often enmesh themselves in the state’s politics to woo voters, but the nature of this race means much less focus on local issues. <div> Donald J. Trump has run his campaign in Iowa in the style of an incumbent, focusing less on local issues in favor of big, national topics.

item.title: The Guide to Iowa via ‘The Run-Up’
item.content:encoded: <div> From under a snowdrift and an Arctic chill, 2024 voting is underway. <div> From under a snowdrift and an Arctic chill, 2024 voting is underway.

item.title: Hamas Says Two More Israeli Hostages Are Dead
item.content:encoded: The group said the two were killed by Israeli airstrikes, which the Israeli military said was at least partly false.

item.title: ‘Happy Days’ Cast Looks Back on 50th Anniversary of Hit Show’s Premiere
item.content:encoded: From left, Donny Most, Henry Winkler, Anson Williams and Ron Howard on the set of “Happy Days.” Five decades later, they remain close.

item.title: ‘Happy Days’ Got Us Unstuck in Time
item.content:encoded: At 50, the classic sitcom is the model of a kind of nostalgia that’s as much about what we forget (the bad stuff) as what we remember. (Aaaay!)

item.title: Biting Cold Hits South With Unfamiliar Freeze, as Several States Declare Emergency
item.content:encoded: Moises Mata spread salt along a sidewalk in Memphis on Monday.

item.title: Grandfather Who Tried to Break Up Fight Is Killed in Subway Shooting
item.content:encoded: Richard Henderson, seen with his wife of 20 years, Jakeba, had been trying to break up an argument between other passengers over loud music when he was shot, the police said.

item.title: Gilgo Beach Serial-Murder Case Hangs on a Single Strand of Hair
item.content:encoded: Crime laboratory officers search Rex Heuermann’s home in Massapequa Park, N.Y., last year.

item.title: Fishing for Scallops When the Scallops Are Nearly All Dead
item.content:encoded: On opening day of bay scallop season this winter, Mike Tehan piloted the only boat on Peconic Bay.

item.title: As Trump Continues to Insult E. Jean Carroll, 2nd Defamation Trial Opens
item.content:encoded: E. Jean Carroll is seeking $10 million for statements Donald J. Trump made in 2019.

item.content:encoded: Joseph Tacopina, center, represented Donald J. Trump in criminal and civil cases in New York.

item.content:encoded: Luisa Rodriguez joined tenants in her San Francisco apartment building in a rent strike.

item.title: Disqualify Trump (or Else)
item.content:encoded: Taking Trump off the ballot has risks, but so does keeping him in place.

item.title: The Responsibility of Republican Voters
item.content:encoded: In Iowa and other states, Republican voters have the opportunity and the obligation to select a presidential candidate who will uphold the rule of law.

item.content:encoded: Oil derricks in the Baku oil field in Azerbaijan in 1912.

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Case That Could Limit Power of Federal Government
item.content:encoded: Bill Bright’s fishing boat, right, in Cape May, N.J. Mr. Bright’s family-owned company is at the center of an upcoming Supreme Court case.

item.title: Workplace Wellness Programs Have Little Benefit, Study Finds
item.content:encoded: Workplace wellness offerings such as apps, coaching and courses in time management or financial well-being did not have any positive effect, according to the study, while resilience and stress management trainings seemed to have a negative effect.

item.title: Iran Adds Prison Time for Narges Mohammadi and Frees 2 Journalists
item.content:encoded: Ali Rahmani, son of Narges Mohammadi, spoke onstage during the 2023 Nobel Peace Prize ceremony at Oslo City Hall in Norway last month.

item.title: Iceland Faces ‘New Chapter’ of Seismic Activity as Lava Menaces Town
item.content:encoded: Lava approaching the town of Grindavik, Iceland, on Sunday. The authorities have ordered residents to evacuate.

item.title: Eric Berryman Channels the Folklore of His Ancestors
item.content:encoded: Eric Berryman’s exploration of African-American folk traditions began in 2013, when a summer program led to his work on “Steel Hammer,” an operatic retelling of the John Henry myth.
